titleStmt.title: Selective Engagement of Cognitive Resources Fail to Account for Age-Related Positive Skew Bias

analytic.title: Selective Engagement of Cognitive Resources Fail to Account for Age-Related Positive Skew Bias

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Sheikh, and Nikita Shrestha for their help in data collection. We would like to thank Sharada Pillai and Israel Smitherman for their help in participant recruitment, data collection, and supervision of research assistants.

div.head: No Effect of Time Pressure During Skewed Risky Decision Making
div.p: Although we rarely think about it as such, car insurance is essentially a gamble (Mossin, 1968). While consumers make the bet that at some point, they will have to file a claim (e.g., if they get into an accident), insurance companies make the bet that consumers will not. For the insurance company, car insurance is what is called a negatively skewed gamble. The insurance company "wins" most of the time, as they collect premiums from most customers each month without having to pay out claims. Yet, when claims are filed that they must pay out to consumers, their losses are quite large. In other words, the insurance company almost always wins, but when they lose, they lose big. For the consumer, car insurance is a positively skewed gamble. Customers pay monthly premiums and they "lose" this money every month they don't file a claim. Yet, on the rare occasion when consumers must file a claim, they often save hundreds to thousands of dollars. That is, consumers rarely win, but when they do, they win big.
Other examples of positively skewed gambles in everyday life include raffles and lottery tickets.

Evidence from both humans and primates show a strong preference for positively skewed gambles, that is, a positive skew bias (Grossman & Eckel, 2015;Mitton & Vorkink, 2008;Strait et al., 2013;Genest et al., 2016), which may be due to differences in how the low probability (i.e., rare) events are weighted when estimating the overall value of each outcome (Hertwig et al., 2004). For positively skewed gambles, the large potential gain amount may be overweighted, thereby making it appear as though it has higher value and therefore, more likely to be chosen. In contrast, for negatively skewed gambles, the large potential loss may be overweighted, appearing to have lower value and thus, less likely to be chosen (Hertwig et al., 2004). Furthermore, recent evidence shows that the extent of positive skew bias may depend on the degree of skewness (Frank et al., 2023), further supporting the idea that skewness may affect how the value of outcomes are weighted.

This preference for positively, relative to negatively, skewed gambles also appears to increase with age (Seaman et al., 2017;Seaman et al., 2018;cf. Frank et al., 2023). Yet relatively little is known about why this age-related increase in positive skew bias occurs. While positively skewed gambles are not necessarily always poor choices, more than 20% of the financial scams are framed as positively skewed lotteries (Federal Bureau of Investigation, 2022). Because older adults own a majority of the wealth in the United States, individuals in later life are frequently targeted for these types of financial schemes. Coupled with the rapidly growing proportion of older adults among the population, there is an urgent need to better understand why this agerelated positive skew bias is happening. Identifying the mechanisms causing skew bias may lead to future interventions to prevent older adults falling victim to certain types of financial scams.

According to the theory of Selective Optimization with Compensation (SOC), the biological constraints that older adults face as they age shift their goals and the strategies that they use to reach those goals (Baltes & Baltes, 1990;Ebner et al., 2006). In the face of dwindling resources, individuals must be more selective in how they employ their resources. As a result, older adults' alter their goals such that they align with their existing resources and often must compensate with their remaining faculties to reach those goals. Moreover, the goals themselves also tend to shift from self-enrichment to maintenance or loss avoidance (Freund, 2006). Thus, it has been hypothesized that loss aversion-the preference to avoid losses rather than accumulate gains (Tversky & Kahneman, 1979)-may increase in older age. While some studies suggest that overall loss aversion does not change with age (Rutledge et al., 2016;Pachur et al., 2017), others find that loss aversion indeed increases in later life (Gachter et al., 2022;Mrkva et al., 2020). If loss aversion does increase in older age, this may partially explain why older adults are selecting the negatively skewed gambles (i.e., those with large losses) less than their younger counterparts.

However, when this was tested in an adult lifespan sample of 508 participants, Seaman and colleagues (2018) found that loss aversion did not impact the propensity to accept positively skewed gambles over negatively skewed gambles and that loss aversion was unrelated to age.

They instead found that individuals who demonstrated greater loss aversion accepted less gambles of all types, regardless of age (Seaman et al., 2018). This suggests that while general loss aversion does seem to play a role in certain types of choices individuals make as they age, it does not appear to be contributing to age-related positive skew bias. However, it may be the case that selective loss avoidance, rather than a general loss aversion, plays a role in the age-related increase in positive skew preference.

Another theory, Selective Engagement of Cognitive Resources (SECR; Hess, 2014), stipulates that the cost of cognitive engagement increases with age. Older adults must compensate for losses by engaging more of their cognitive resources to produce the same outcome as younger adults. These larger costs (e.g., increased fatigue) directly affect the motivation of older adults to engage in cognitively demanding tasks (Hess, 2014). As such, the SECR posits that older adults are less likely to engage their limited cognitive resources for tasks that are less aligned with their goals. If older adults shift their goals toward maintenance and the prevention of losses as claimed by the SOC theory, and prioritize using their limited resources for tasks that are aligned with their goals as asserted by the SECR, older adults may be selectively engaging their cognitive control resources for the negatively skewed gambles to avoid the large potential losses.

Initial support of this idea comes from neuroimaging evidence that examined activation of lateral prefrontal regions of the brain during skewed gambling tasks in younger and older adults (Seaman et al., 2017). They found that older adults recruited more overall neural resources than younger adults during the skewed decision-making tasks. More specifically, they found that in older adults, negatively, compared to positively, skewed gambles were associated with greater activation in the anterior insula (AI), left inferior frontal gyrus (IFG), and anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) (Seaman et al., 2017)-regions thought to be associated with deliberate cognitive control (Botvinick & Braver, 2015;Goghari & MacDonald III, 2009;Power & Peterson, 2013).

Moreover, older adults were slower to make a choice for negatively skewed gambles relative to positively skewed gambles, whereas younger adults showed the opposite pattern (Seaman et al., 2017). Taken together, these findings suggest that older adults may be engaging in greater cognitive control when faced with negatively skewed gambles.

If this is the case, it may be that older adults are choosing to engage greater cognitive control to avoid the large potential losses and maintain status quo. In comparison, for positively skewed gambles, the associated losses tend to be smaller so individuals may feel that evaluating those potential losses to the same degree is not worth the cognitive cost. Instead, older adults may be using a heuristic (i.e., rule of thumb) or relying on less cognitively demanding processes to make choices for positively skewed gambles. Based on these assumptions, it may be that older adults may not simply prefer positively skewed gambles but are instead selectively engaging their cognitive resources to avoid negatively skewed gambles. If the age-related positive skew bias is caused by selective engagement of cognitive control on gambles with larger potential losses, then imposing an experimental condition that prohibits the engagement of cognitive control should eliminate this bias.

One way to experimentally manipulate cognitive control demands during decision making is with time pressure, or limiting of the amount of time an individual has to make a choice (Svenson, 1993;Otto et al., 2013;. Cognitive control takes time (Suter et al., 2011) and the cost of cognitive control can be indexed by the amount of time an individual spends making a decision (Payne et al., 1993). Because older adults in particular need more time to engage their cognitive resources to make choices (Deakin et al., 2003), these time pressure manipulations have been shown to be particularly effective in older participants (Gamble et al., 2014;Wasylyshyn et al., 2011). Therefore, by leveraging time pressure, we can experimentally reduce cognitive control during decision making and see if the age-related increase in positive skew bias is extinguished.

In this preregistered study (https://osf.io/ugf6s/) we investigate the role of cognitive control during skewed decision making across the adult lifespan (ages 25-85). Individuals make a series of choices between a certain, safe option (no winning or losing additional money), and an uncertain skewed option (chance of winning or losing money with some probability) under both time pressure and no time pressure. If older adults selectively engage their cognitive resources during negatively skewed gambles to avoid large potential losses, we would expect to see that under time pressure, there would be a reduction in the positive skew bias (i.e., increase in choosing negatively skewed gambles) in older age. We expect that this time pressure manipulation will only influence skew bias in later life (ages 65+), where cognitive resources are limited.

div.head: Participants
div.p: To determine the number of required participants, we conducted an a priori power analysis using an effect size observed in a prior study with an age by time pressure interaction (Earles et al., 2004) with an alpha = .05 and power = .80. This estimated the minimum sample size to be 78 participants. We recruited 103 total participants between the ages of 25 and 85 using a lifespan sampling strategy to combat overestimation of age effects that can occur in extreme group designs (Isaacowitz & Lind, 2019). Enrollment targets for age and gender were used to ensure a uniform, representative distribution across the adult lifespan. To ensure the cognitive health of older adult participants, individuals who were 55 or older completed the Short Blessed Test (SBT;Katzman et al., 1983) phone screening before being invited to participate and were then given the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA; Nasreddine et al., 2005) at the time of assessment. Individuals with scores of 25 or below on the MoCA were excluded from further testing (N = 12). Participants were excluded from analysis if they had incomplete data (N =4), missing responses from ≥20% of trials in either condition (N = 9), had extremely fast reaction times (≥ 2 standard deviations below the sample mean), always chose the same response key, or accepted or rejected all gambles presented. Recruitment continued until we reached a total of 78 participants (mean age = 54.9(SD = 16.1), 50% female, 69% white, 14% Black, 7% Asian, 4% Multiracial, and 5% other) in our analytic sample.

div.head: Skewed Gambling Task
div.p: Participants completed a variant of the Skewed Gambling Task (Seaman et al., 2017;Seaman et al., 2018). In this task, participants see pairs of gambles on the screen and choose between a certain-that is, no chance of winning or losing any additional money-and an uncertain gamble ( Figure 1B). There are three types of uncertain gambles: symmetric, positively skewed, and negatively skewed ( Figure 1A). Symmetric gambles feature an equal probability of winning or losing an amount (e.g., 50% chance of winning or losing $22.36). Positively skewed gambles feature a small probability of winning a large amount coupled with a large probability of losing a small amount (e.g., 10% chance of winning $67.08 with a 90% chance of losing $7.45). Conversely, negatively skewed gambles feature a small probability of losing a large amount coupled with a large probability of winning a small amount (e.g., 10% chance of losing $67.08 with a 90% chance of winning $7.45). Skewed gambles varied systematically in the degree of skewness on each trial, spanning from maximum uncertainty (50/50 gamble) to nearcertainty (95% win) in 5% increments (skewness = 0.2 to 4.5). All gambles had an expected value of $0. The 200 trials were presented over ten blocks (20 trials: two symmetric gambles, nine positively skewed gambles, and nine negatively skewed gambles per block). Each gamble appeared once per block with the order of gambles randomized for each participant. Five blocks had a 4-second decision window (no time pressure condition) and five blocks had a 2-second decision window (time pressure condition). If a choice was not made within the decision window, participants saw the message "Your response was too slow. Please speed up." Participants were endowed with $10 at the beginning of the task and did not receive any feedback on their choices during the task. Their choices were incentive compatible such that at the end of the testing session, we randomly selected one gamble from the session to play out and the participant's final compensation was based on their choice for that gamble. This was in addition to their hourly compensation.

Each trial was scored such that rejecting the gamble (i.e., choosing the safe option) was recorded as 0, and accepting the gamble was recorded as 1. Responses were then averaged across trials to determine gamble acceptance rate, calculated separately for positively skewed and negatively skewed gambles. Skew bias scores were calculated as gamble acceptance rate for positively skewed gambles minus the acceptance rate for negatively skewed gambles, reflecting how much more an individual chose positively, compared to negatively, skewed gambles.

div.head: Additional Measures
div.p: In addition to the skewed gambling task, participants completed a demographic questionnaire, the Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (ERQ; Gross & John, 2003) , the Affect Valuation Index (AVI; Tsai, Knutson, & Fung, 2006), Subjective numeracy (Fagerlin et a;, objective numeracy (Cokely et al., 2012), subjective graph literacy (Garcia-Retamero et al., 2016), objective graph literacy (Okan et al., 2019), and a detailed questionnaire about their assets and real-world financial decisions. Participants also completed the Cognition Battery of the NIH Toolbox (Weintraub et al., 2013) that tested executive function, processing speed, language, working memory, and episodic memory.

div.head: Data Analysis
div.p: We used hierarchical linear regression models to examine the effect of time pressure and age on skew bias scores. In the baseline model, we tested the effect of experimental condition (time pressure vs. no time pressure) on skew bias score. In the age model, we added age as a continuous variable and its interaction with experimental condition as predictors.
Baseline Model:
Age Model:

div.head: Deviations from Preregistration
div.p: While the preregistration stated that each trial in the time pressure condition blocks would have a 1-second decision window, due to a programming error, these trials instead had a 2-second decision window. The no pressure condition was not affected and included a 4-second decision window as preregistered. This change and its possible effects are further addressed in the discussion.

div.head: Results
div.p: Overall, time pressure condition did not have a significant effect on skew bias scores (baseline model: p = 0.997; see Table 1 for model output). When age was added as a predictor, time pressure condition was still not a significant predictor of skew bias (age model: p = 0.998),

nor was there an age by condition interaction (p = 0.976). Furthermore, there was not a significant main effect of age (p = 0.149). However, because the estimate of the condition effect was negligible (beta estimate = 0), we also ran a model collapsed across time pressure conditions. In this model, age indeed significantly predicted skew bias such that older age was associated with larger positive skew bias, β = 0.08, p = .044. This age-related effect can be seen in Figure 2 such that there is an increase in gamble acceptance for positively skewed gambles across the adult lifespan and a decrease in gamble acceptance for negatively skewed gambles across the adult lifespan. This pattern occurs both under time pressure and with no time constraint, and there was substantial individual variability in how skew bias changed between the two conditions (see Figure 3).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In this study, we examined whether the age-related increase in positive skew bias was driven by selective loss avoidance of negatively skewed gambles. Using a time pressure manipulation intended to reduce cognitive control engagement, we tested the preference for skewed gambles across adulthood. Contrary to our hypothesis, we found that time pressure did not impact skew bias at any age. We did, however, replicate previous findings of an age-related increase in positive skew bias such that older adults were more likely to demonstrate a positive skew bias.

The time pressure manipulation used here did not influence skew bias or gamble preferences. While we expected this to be the case for younger adults, we predicted that older adults' positive skew bias would be reduced when making decisions under time pressure. When we examine individuals' change in skew bias between the two conditions (see Figure 3), it appears that the direction of change was highly variable depending on the participant. That is, skew bias scores increased for some individuals and decreased for others during the time pressure manipulation (See Figure 3).

One possible explanation for the absence of an effect may be the strength of the time pressure manipulation. As mentioned in the method section, the decision window in the time pressure condition (two-seconds) was not as strong as originally planned (one-second), which may have affected the outcomes. When we compared the response times between conditions, participants were indeed faster to respond during the two-second (M = 1.06 seconds, SD = 0.39), compared to the 4-second (M = 1.78 seconds, SD = 0.79, decision window (p < .001),

suggesting the manipulation indeed worked to some extent. However, the mean response time for both conditions was under two seconds, making it is unclear whether this time window was sufficient to engage cognitive control. Thus, it is possible that this manipulation was not strong In conclusion, this study examined the age-related positive skew bias in risky decision making across participants aged 25 to 85. These findings provide initial evidence that the agerelated positive skew bias cannot be explained by selective engagement of cognitive control on gambles with larger potential losses (i.e., negatively skewed). Thus, additional research is needed to elucidate the mechanistic underpinnings of increased positive skew bias seen in older age. A better understanding why older adults are more attracted to these positively skewed gambles will allow us to predict who will need the most help navigating the increasingly complex financial landscape, and how to best help them do so.

div.head: Figure 1
div.p: The Skewed Gambling Task with the three types of gambles (A) and a sample trial (B)

div.head: Figure 3
div.p: Difference in skew bias scores between condition (time pressure vs. none) for each participant

figure.figDesc: enough reduce available resources and eliminate the age-related positive-skew bias.Alternatively, the persistence of a positive skew bias in the face of time pressure may suggest that selective engagement of cognitive control on gambles with larger potential losses (i.e., negatively skewed) cannot account for the age-related increase in positive skew bias. Thus, the mechanisms underlying the age-related changes in skew bias remain unknown. One alternative hypothesis is that instead of changes to motivation and cognition later in life driving selective loss avoidance to explain the positive skew bias, it may be related to the increased attention to and memory for positive information seen in older age (i.e., positivity effect;Mather & Carstensen, 2005). Older adults may be selectively attending to the larger potential gains of positively skewed gambles. This may partially explain the overall increase in preference for the positively skewed gambles in later life. Future work testing this, and other, hypotheses would provide a clearer understanding of the factors that do and do not contribute to the age-related positive skew bias.The present study also had a number of limitations. For one, in-person data collection began in February 2022, just weeks after the peak number of reported COVID-19 cases in Dallas County during the entirety of the pandemic. This made recruitment and data collection challenging and participants who chose to participate were engaging in a sort of skewed gamble as participation in the study came with an increased possibility contracting COVID-19 due to the close contact with experimenters. For certain populations, including older adults, the risks associated with developing COVID-19, although relatively small, could be catastrophic, indicating a strongly negatively skewed gamble. Thus, the participants who opted to participate in our study may have been more willing to take skewed risky decisions than the general population. Additionally, as discussed above, we cannot ensure that constraining the decision window time to two seconds affected cognitive control sufficiently or similarly across individuals. Studies that use alternative manipulations of cognitive control, such as dual-task TIME PRESSURE DURING SKEWED DECISION MAKING 14 paradigms, may further elucidate the role of cognitive control in the age-related positive skew bias.
